official-title.#text: Expressing the sense of the House of Representatives that both Houses of Congress should reconvene on or before December 18, 2013, to take appropriate action to enact legislation extending the Emergency Unemployment Compensation Program until January 1, 2015.

sponsor.#tail: submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: that both Houses of Congress should reconvene on or before December 18, 2013, to take appropriate action to enact legislation extending the Emergency Unemployment Compensation Program until January 1, 2015.

text.#text: Whereas the Emergency Unemployment Compensation Program (hereinafter referred to as the
Whereas the EUC Program is the 8th time Congress has created a Federal temporary program that has extended unemployment compensation during an economic slowdown;
Whereas the authorization for the EUC Program expires December 28, 2013;

Whereas unless the EUC Program is extended, more than 1,300,000 jobless workers will have their benefits cut off on December 28, 2013, and nearly another 1,900,000 jobless workers will lose their unemployment benefits between January 1 and June 30, 2014;
Whereas it is estimated that failure to extend the EUC Program will result in a loss of 310,000 jobs next year because of reduced consumer demand;
Whereas it is estimated that failure to extend the EUC Program will reduce economic growth by as much as 0.4 percent in the first quarter of 2014;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: reported in 2012 that assistance for the unemployed has one of the

quote.#tail: because financially stressed unemployed workers spend any benefits they receive quickly;
quote.#text: largest effects on employment per dollar of budgetary cost

text.#text: Whereas failure to extend the EUC Program will further hurt an economy already injured by the loss of an estimated 750,000 jobs resulting from budget cuts mandated by sequestration and the loss of more than 120,000 jobs in the first 2 weeks of October 2013 as a consequence of the shutdown of the Federal Government;

Whereas 36 percent of unemployed workers have been out of work for more than 6 months, in part because the national economy still has 2,000,000 fewer jobs than before the Great Recession began in 2008; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: does not act immediately to extend these benefits, a devastating blow will be dealt not only to the millions of Americans who are already struggling, but to our economy: Now, therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 110 HRES 446 IH: Expressing the sense of the House of Representatives that both Houses of Congress should reconvene on or before December 18, 2013, to take appropriate action to enact legislation extending the Emergency Unemployment Compensation Program until January 1, 2015.
